title: Getting started with the tumr package
code: library(tumr) data("melanoma2") plot_mean <- function(data, group, time, measure, id, stat = median, remove_na = FALSE){   data_summary <- data |>     dplyr::group_by({{group}}, {{time}}) |>     dplyr::summarise(measure = stat({{measure}}, na.rm = remove_na), .groups = "drop_last") |>     dplyr::ungroup()    if (remove_na == TRUE) {     data_full <- data |>       na.omit(data)   } else {     data_full <- data   }    ggplot2::ggplot() +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_full,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = {{measure}},                                     group = {{id}},                                     color = {{group}}),                        alpha = 0.5)  +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_summary,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = measure,                                     color = {{group}}),                        linewidth = 1.2) +     ggplot2::labs(             y = "Volume",             title = "Volume over Time"           )  } mel2 <- tumr(melanoma2, ID, Day, Volume, Treatment) plot_mean(melanoma2, Treatment, Day, Volume, ID, stat = mean) plot_median(mel2) (rfeat_mel2 <- rfeat(mel2, comparison = "both")) $anova             Df   Sum Sq   Mean Sq F value Pr(>F) Group        4 0.008424 0.0021061   2.938 0.0314 * Residuals   42 0.030106 0.0007168 --- Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1  $tukey   Tukey multiple comparisons of means     95% family-wise confidence level  Fit: aov(formula = Beta ~ Group, data = 0.010436327 0.2941216 E-A -0.030852007 -0.06704348  0.005339465 0.1274422 C-B  0.012207393 -0.02284927  0.047264052 0.8572838 D-B  0.015877390 -0.01917927  0.050934049 0.6982531 E-B  0.008710703 -0.02836362  0.045785023 0.9618601 D-C  0.003669997 -0.03045165  0.037791644 0.9980027 E-C -0.003496690 -0.03968816  0.032694782 0.9986875 E-D -0.007166687 -0.04335816  0.029024785 0.9794890 plot(rfeat_mel2) lmm_mel2 <- lmm(mel2) Warning in checkConv(attr(opt, "derivs"), opt$par, ctrl = control$checkConv, : Model failed to converge with max|grad| = 0.00566844 (tol = 0.002, component 1) title: Getting started with the tumr package
code: plot_mean <- function(data, group, time, measure, id, stat = median, remove_na = FALSE){   data_summary <- data |>     dplyr::group_by({{group}}, {{time}}) |>     dplyr::summarise(measure = stat({{measure}}, na.rm = remove_na), .groups = "drop_last") |>     dplyr::ungroup()    if (remove_na == TRUE) {     data_full <- data |>       na.omit(data)   } else {     data_full <- data   }    ggplot2::ggplot() +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_full,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = {{measure}},                                     group = {{id}},                                     color = {{group}}),                        alpha = 0.5)  +     ggplot2::geom_line(data = data_summary,                        ggplot2::aes(x = {{time}},                                     y = measure,                                     color = {{group}}),                        linewidth = 1.2) +     ggplot2::labs(             y = "Volume",             title = "Volume over Time"           )  }

what: Plotting the Mean vs the Median
title: Getting started with the tumr package
code: mel2 <- tumr(melanoma2, ID, Day, Volume, Treatment) plot_mean(melanoma2, Treatment, Day, Volume, ID, stat = mean) plot_median(mel2)

code: pros_meta <- tumr(prostate, ID, Age, BLI, Genotype)  plot_median(pros_meta) (pros_rfeat <- rfeat(pros_meta, comparison = "both")) $anova             Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq F value   Pr(>F) Group        2 0.14850 0.07425   62.41 7.86e-14 *** Residuals   46 0.05473 0.00119 --- Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1  $tukey   Tukey multiple comparisons of means     95% family-wise confidence level  Fit: aov(formula = Beta ~ Group, data = betas)  $Group                  diff         lwr         upr     p adj HET-DOKO -0.110898513 -0.13955117 -0.08224585 0.0000000 WT-DOKO  -0.120444046 -0.15003639 -0.09085170 0.0000000 WT-HET   -0.009545533 -0.03913787  0.02004681 0.7163468 plot(pros_rfeat) (pros_lmm <- lmm(pros_meta)) Warning in checkConv(attr(opt, "derivs"), opt$par, ctrl = control$checkConv, : Model failed to converge with max|grad| = 0.00478111 (tol = 0.002, component 1)   See ?lme4::convergence and ?lme4::troubleshooting. Linear mixed model fit by REML. t-tests use Satterthwaite's method [ lmerModLmerTest] Formula: log1p(BLI) ~ Genotype * Age + (Age | ID)    Data: data  REML criterion at convergence: 1423.8  Scaled residuals:     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max -5.2046 -0.4834  0.0116  0.5532  3.2088  Random effects:  Groups   Name        Variance  Std.Dev. Corr  ID       (Intercept) 0.1824792 0.42718           Age         0.0006397 0.02529  -0.91  Residual             0.4264456 0.65303 Number of obs: 662, groups:  ID, 49  Fixed effects:                  Estimate Std. title: Authors and Citation
text: Patrick Breheny. Author, maintainer. Sydney Plowman. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Breheny P, Plowman S (2025). tumr: Analysis Power Calculations Tumor Growth Rates. R package version 0.5.1, https://pbreheny.github.io/tumr/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {tumr: Analysis and Power Calculations for Tumor Growth Rates},   author = {Patrick Breheny and Sydney Plowman},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.5.1},   url = {https://pbreheny.github.io/tumr/}, }

what: Analysis and Power Calculations for Tumor Growth Rates
title: Analysis and Power Calculations for Tumor Growth Rates
text: tumr collection tools analyzing tumor growth data. example use tumr can seen Get Started page. tumr includes: tumr() - creates tumr object can passed plot_median(), rfeat(), lmm(). plot_median() - creates spaghetti plot plots median tumor growth measurement treatment group. rfeat() - tests whether beta coefficients (slope tumor measure time) individuals different treatment groups different using either t-test, ANOVA, Tukey, ANOVA Tukey. rfeat() plot() function shows individual beta coefficients mean slope treatment group. lmm() - fits linear mixed model default formula log1p(Volume) ~ Treatment * scale(Day) + (scale(Day) | ID) time variable centered. lmm() includes summary() function provides overall effect time averaged levels treatment group, slope treatment time treatment group, results contrast test slope differences treatment groups. lmm() includes plot() function shows predicted values tumor growth measurements time mean slope treatment 95% confidence intervals.

title: Analysis and Power Calculations for Tumor Growth Rates
text: install tumr, copy paste following code console

(factor) Treatment Treatment group (factor). VEH = control (vehicle), NR = nicotinamide riboside Week Week measurment (integer) Volume Tumor volume, cubic mm (double) Number Number tumors (integer)

text: n Number mice per group effect_size Vector effect sizes, growth ratio (default: 2) m Number measurements per mouse (default: 3) alpha Shape parameter gamma distribution (default: 9) sd Noise (standard deviation, default: 100)

title: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
text: Y            Observed measurements M            Idealized 'true' size mouse time (error) B            'True' growth rate mouse (data-generating mechanism)

title: Generate tumor data: Time to reach endpoint — gendat
code: Data <- gendat(5, effect_size=2, m=6) matplot(Data$time, t(Data$Y[,,1]), lty=1, type='l', col='#FF4E37', bty='n', las=1,         ylab=expression("Tumor volume "*(mm^3)), xlab='Day') matplot(Data$time, t(Data$Y[,,2]), lty=1, type='l', col='#008DFF', add=TRUE)
